meanings.sent1: She decided to reinvent her room by painting it a bright color.
meanings.sent2: The company needed to reinvent its marketing strategy to attract more customers.
meanings.sent3: He tried to reinvent his hairstyle by using a mop as a wig - it didn't work.
meanings.sent4: After the storm, the garden looked like nature had reinvented it overnight.
meanings.sent5: The artist's brush seemed to reinvent the canvas with every stroke.

meanings.definition: To bring back into existence or use
meanings.sent1: The museum decided to reinvent an old exhibit to showcase it in a new light.
meanings.sent2: She wanted to reinvent the family tradition of Sunday picnics in the park.
meanings.sent3: The magician tried to reinvent an ancient spell, but it only made his hat disappear.
meanings.sent4: The old clock seemed to reinvent time itself with its steady ticking.
meanings.sent5: The chef's secret recipe reinvented the forgotten flavors of the past.

meanings.definition: To make as if for the first time; give a new form to
meanings.sent1: The designer aimed to reinvent the classic dress by adding a modern twist.
meanings.sent2: He wanted to reinvent the way people interacted with technology through his invention.
meanings.sent3: The comedian tried to reinvent an old joke, but the audience didn't find it funny.
meanings.sent4: Her smile seemed to reinvent happiness every time she entered the room.
meanings.sent5: The author's words had the power to reinvent reality within the reader's mind.
